story:
Once upon a time, in a small village in Indonesia, there was a little girl named Sari. Sari was a kind and curious girl who loved to explore the world around her. She lived with her mother and father in a cozy wooden house near a lush jungle filled with all sorts of fascinating animals and plants.

One day, Sari's mother told her a story about a magical bird that lived deep in the jungle. The bird was said to have the most beautiful feathers in the world, shimmering in all the colors of the rainbow. But the bird was also very elusive and rarely seen by humans.

Sari was fascinated by the story and begged her mother to take her to see the magical bird. Her mother warned her that it would be a dangerous journey, but Sari was determined to see the bird for herself.

The next day, Sari and her mother set out into the jungle, armed with a map and supplies. They hiked for hours, climbing over rocks and wading through streams. As they went deeper into the jungle, they saw all sorts of amazing creatures - monkeys swinging from tree to tree, colorful butterflies flitting through the air, and even a family of orangutans playing in the river.

Finally, they reached a clearing where they saw the most beautiful bird they had ever laid eyes on. The bird had feathers in every color of the rainbow, and they shimmered and sparkled in the sunlight. Sari was in awe of the bird's beauty.

But as they watched, they noticed something strange. The bird was trapped in a cage, unable to fly free. Sari's heart ached for the bird, and she knew she had to help it.

Using her quick thinking, Sari found a long vine and swung it over to the cage. The bird hopped onto the vine, and Sari slowly lowered it to the ground. The bird was now free!

Sari and her mother watched as the bird soared into the sky, leaving a trail of rainbow-colored feathers behind. They knew they had done something truly special for this magical creature.

As they made their way back home, Sari realized that the most beautiful things in life are often the most elusive. And she learned that with courage and kindness, she could make a real difference in the world.

From that day on, Sari always remembered the magical bird and the lesson it had taught her. And whenever she faced a challenge, she would think of the bird and find the strength to overcome it.

And with that, my dear daughter, it's time to close your eyes and dream of magical birds and the wonders of the world. Good night, and sweet dreams.
